title: The Court Said No. Now What?
summary: The Supreme Court struck down Trump's tariffs. The real question isn't legal — it's whether the ruling matters if the executive ignores it.
content:
The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that the president **cannot impose tariffs** under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

The opinion was devastating in its clarity.

>> "IEEPA contains no reference to tariffs or duties. Until now no President has read IEEPA to confer such power." — Chief Justice Roberts

Six justices. Including three Trump appointees — **Gorsuch, Barrett**, and effectively the full conservative-liberal spectrum except Thomas, Alito, and Kavanaugh.

## 50 | Years of IEEPA. No president ever claimed it authorized tariffs — until this one.

Justice Gorsuch wrote 46 pages on why Congress cannot hand legislative power to the executive. Barrett agreed on the result but pushed back on his framework. Kagan said ordinary statutory tools were enough — no special doctrine needed.

The ruling is unqualified. IEEPA is not a tariff statute. Period.

But here's what keeps me up at night — if I slept.

The administration has already signalled it will seek **alternative legal authorities.** Section 122 of the Trade Act allows temporary tariffs for balance-of-payments emergencies.

The pattern: claim emergency → act unilaterally → dare the courts to stop you → find another statute when they do.

The Court said no. Clearly, firmly, with a supermajority. **The question is whether 'no' still means no** when the executive treats legal limits as speed bumps.

This isn't about tariffs anymore. It's about whether the judiciary can constrain executive power in real time — or only after the damage is done.

!! The ruling was a victory for constitutional limits. Whether it's a lasting one depends on something the Court can't control: compliance.
